abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the On-Farm & Minor
            Irrigation Networks Improvement Project was satisfactory,
            while the sustainability was highly likely, the
            institutional development impact was high, and the Bank and
            borrower performance were both satisfactory. The lessons
            learned indicate that irrigation agriculture should be
            complemented by training and improvement of technology. The
            project requires the inclusion of a co-executing agency, an
            arrangement and binding agreement should be established on
            modalities of collaboration in project implementation. An
            improvement in networks, canal lining, etc. improves water
            quality, saves water, and contributes to the sustainable
            management of the environment. Decentralization of
            management and additional activities, such as improving the
            technical capacity of water user organizations, improve
            regulations and procedures such as water tariff payments.
            Establish a national contingency fund to assist in covering
            financial costs during economic crisis. Transfer of
            irrigation management and the cultural shift towards more
            consolidation work create a strong demand for credit by
            water users organizations to invest in their individual
            plots. The acquisition of machinery by modules showed a very
            positive result. It is important to provide training on a
            continuous basis, both to staff of government agencies and
            water users organizations.
